qas.question: Who was the architect of the Gregorian calendar?
What did the architects of the calendar notice about the astronomical tables?
Whose solution to the discrepancies of the tables would have been agreeable to astronomers?
When did Pitatus offer his solution to the leap year problem?
What is the theory about leap year called?
What provided the sons mean latitude?
Who noticed that the tables agreed on the time the sun passed the vernal equinox?
Who suggested ninety-seven leap years in 400 years during the fifteenth century
Who solution to discrepancies in the tables was not agreeable to astronomers?

context: <b5_0>Ancient tables<b5_0/> provided the sun's mean longitude. <a0_0><b6_0>Christopher Clavius<b6_0/><a0_0/>, the architect of the <b9_0>Gregorian calendar,<b9_0/> noted that the tables agreed neither on the time when the sun passed through the vernal equinox nor on the length of the mean tropical year. Tycho Brahe also noticed <a1_0>discrepancies<a1_0/>. The <a4_0>Gregorian leap year rule<a4_0/> (97 leap years in 400 years) was put forward by <a2_0><b7_0>Petrus <b8_0>Pitatus<b7_0/><a2_0/> of Verona<b8_0/> in <a3_0>1560<a3_0/>. He noted that it is consistent with the tropical year of the Alfonsine tables and with the mean tropical year of Copernicus (De revolutionibus) and Reinhold (Prutenic tables). The three mean tropical years in Babylonian sexagesimals as the excess over 365 days (the way they would have been extracted from the tables of mean longitude) were 14,33,9,57 (Alphonsine), 14,33,11,12 (Copernicus) and 14,33,9,24 (Reinhold). All values are the same to two places (14:33) and this is also the mean length of the Gregorian year. Thus Pitatus' solution would have commended itself to the astronomers.
